item.description: Dong, H., and Y. Gao. “Existence and uniqueness of bounded stable solutions to the Peierls–Nabarro model for curved dislocations.” Calculus of Variations and Partial Differential Equations 60, no. 2 (April 1, 2021). https://doi.org/10.1007/s00526-021-01939-1. Full text here: Gao, Y., X. Y. Lu, and C. Wang. “Regularity and monotonicity for solutions to a continuum model of epitaxial growth with nonlocal elastic effects.” Advances in Calculus of Variations, January 1, 2021. https://doi.org/10.1515/acv-2020-0114. Full text here: Gao, Y.

item.title: Activities | Dr. Yuan Gao
item.description: Upcoming Activities We are organizing PSU-Purdue-UMD Joint Seminar on Mathematical Data Science. Time: 10:30 - 11:30 AM ET on Mondays. December 2024: Invited speaker in Biophysical Seminars at Physics department, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN, December 3, 2024. November 2024: Invited speaker in seminar at the Center for Stability, Instability, and Turbulence, NYU Abu Dhabi, online, November 20, 2024. Invited speaker in Numerical Analysis Seminar, University of Maryland, College Park, MD, November 5, 2024.

item.title: Dr. Yuan Gao
item.description: Yuan Gao Assistant Professor of Mathematics Department of Mathematics, Purdue University Email：gao662@purdue.edu Find me on Google Scholar or ResearchGate. I mainly work on analysis/computations for PDEs from materials sciences, biology, and microfluids. I recently focus on optimal control and Hamilton-Jacobi equations with applications in transition path theory, mean-field limit, large deviation principle and non-equilibrium chemical reactions. My research is supported by NSF Award DMS-2204288. PSU-Purdue-UMD Joint Seminar on Mathematical Data Science Appointments & Affiliations Assistant Professor of Mathematics, Department of Mathematics, Purdue University, 2021-Now William W.

Stephan. “Fast-slow chemical reactions: convergence of Hamilton-Jacobi equation and variational representation”, submitted. https://arxiv.org/abs/2412.14411v1 [4] Gao, Y., Q. J. Lang, F. Lu. “Self-test loss functions for learning weak-form operators and gradient flows”, submitted. https://arxiv.org/abs/2412.03506 [3]Gao, Y., W. Li, J. -G. Liu. “Fluctuations in Wasserstein dynamics on Graphs”, submitted.

item.title: Research | Dr. Yuan Gao
item.description: Recent Projects 1. Macroscopic Dynamics for Nonequilibrium Chemical Reactions Most biochemical reactions in living cells are an open system interacting with the environment through chemostats. At a mesoscopic scale, the molecular number of each species in those biochemical reactions can be modeled by the random time-changed Poisson processes. To characterize the macroscopic behaviors in the large volume limit, the law of large numbers in path space determines a mean-field limit nonlinear ODE.
